item.title: Turkey's Inflation Rate Picks Up Pace Again
item.description: Turkey’s consumer price index increased by 61.5% in September, just above expectations, suggesting the country may need to further increase already high interest rates as it battles to rein in rampant price rises.

item.title: Gold, Copper Move to Multi-Month Lows on Rate Hike Prospects
item.description: Base metals and gold prices were falling in early London trading, with the prospect of further monetary tightening from central banks adding pressure to commodity markets.

item.title: Crude Oil Slips on Macro Headwinds
item.description: Crude oil prices moved lower in Europe, as the prospect of more rate hikes and uncertain demand pegged back key benchmarks.

item.title: Dollar Climbs to Multi-Month Highs as US Bond Yields Rise Further
item.description: The dollar hit its highest since late last year against a basket of currencies and the euro as U.S. government-bond yields rose further.

item.title: Ford, GM Lay Off About 500 Factory Workers as Strike Effects Ripple Out
item.description: Ford and GM laid off an additional 500 workers combined, knock-on effects from the United Auto Workers’ ongoing strike.

item.title: What Is a Motion to Vacate, and How Could McCarthy Defeat It?
item.description: Rep. Matt Gaetz took to the House floor to formally present a resolution to oust Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Here’s what happens next.

item.title: Sika Ups Midterm Earnings Targets
item.description: Sika lifted its midterm earnings guidance to between 6% and 9% to 2028, on the back of a new business strategy and what the company called a strong market position.

item.title: Mining Old Sites Can be a Shortcut to More Copper for the Energy Transition
item.description: Companies scrambling to increase supplies of critical materials are finding some luck in reopening sites.

item.title: Nikkei Falls 1.6% as Energy, Auto Stocks Drag
item.description: Japanese stocks ended broadly lower, dragged by falls in energy and auto stocks as concerns about the scope of policy tightening by central banks and higher borrowing costs persist.

item.title: China Evergrande Group's Shares Jump as Trade Resumes
item.description: China Evergrande Group’s shares rose sharply as trade resumed after being halted last week, following news the property developer’s chairman was being investigated by authorities.

item.title: Inside Ukraine's Fight to Retake Bakhmut: 'The Ground Was Covered in Bodies'
item.description: A soldier’s ground-level view of the costly battle—against a much larger Russian force—for a tiny village outside the ruined city.

item.title: Criminal Gangs Exploit Security Gaps to Infiltrate Airports
item.description: A postpandemic hiring spree has created vulnerabilities as new staff gain access to secure areas.

item.title: Meta Floats Charging $14 a Month for Ad-Free Instagram
item.description: European users would have the option to pay a fee or agree to personalized ads, according to the company’s pitch to regulators.

item.title: Italy, Land of Uncollected Garbage, Combines Running With Trash Pickup
item.description: At the World Plogging Championship, contestants have lugged in tires, TVs and at least one Neapolitan coffee maker.

item.title: Thailand's Charoen Pokphand Foods Delays IPO of Unit, Sources Say
item.description: CPF Global Food Solution, a company owned by one of the world’s largest animal feed and livestock producers, is delaying its initial public offering.

item.title: Congressman's Car Stolen at Gunpoint in Washington
item.description: Rep. Henry Cuellar of Texas was carjacked Monday night, as the nation’s capital struggles with a surge in crime.

item.title: Can the World's Longest Tunnel Solve One of Europe's Worst Bottlenecks?
item.description: When it’s completed in 2032, the Brenner Base Tunnel nestled in the Alps between Austria and Italy will provide a critical link in a corridor connecting ports in Scandinavia to the Mediterranean. WSJ explores what it will take to complete and what it could mean for trade in the region.

item.title: Boaz Weinstein and his group of high-profile investors sweetened their previous offer for hedge-fund firm Sculptor, according to people close to the matter.
item.description: Boaz Weinstein and his group of high-profile investors sweetened their previous offer for hedge-fund firm Sculptor, according to people close to the matter.

item.title: U.S. stocks ended mixed, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq adding 0.01% and 0.7%, respectively, while the Dow industrials fell 0.2%.
item.description: U.S. stocks ended mixed, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq adding 0.01% and 0.7%, respectively, while the Dow industrials fell 0.2%.

item.title: Ford and GM have laid off an additional 500 workers combined, knock-on effects from the United Auto Workers' strike.
item.description: Ford and GM have laid off an additional 500 workers combined, knock-on effects from the United Auto Workers’ strike.
